<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Ffeatured%20insights%2Ffood%20security%2Fdigital%20transformation%20comes%20to%20food%20banks%2Fdigital-transformation-comes-to-food-banks-vf.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="digital-transformation-comes-to-food-banks-vf" data-layer-report-name="digital-transformation-comes-to-food-banks-vf>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (7 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Companies aren’t </strong>the only organizations remaking themselves into digital enterprises to meet customers’ needs. When the COVID-19 pandemic hit, food banks<a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/digital-transformation-improving-the-odds-of-success"> accelerated their digital trans­formations</a> to get more food more quickly to more people in need.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-left-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>When the COVID-19 pandemic hit, food banks accelerated their digital transformations to get more food more quickly to more people in need.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>One of them is The Greater Boston Food Bank (GBFB), which estimates it distributed 56 percent more food in 2020 than the previous year because of the pandemic.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="baa376a3-5daa-49cd-be13-840c6e78d2a9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="baa376a3-5daa-49cd-be13-840c6e78d2a9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Company fact sheet,” The Greater Boston Food Bank, March 18, 2021, gbfb.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Although crisis-related hardships have begun to recede, demand for charitable food aid in GBFB’s eastern Massachusetts service area remains significant. It prompted the food bank’s leaders to rethink their practice of adopting technology in a piecemeal fashion. Instead, they’re in the initial phase of implementing an approximately three-year, $5 million plan—dubbed “Project Everest”—to operate as a unified, digital-first organization.</p>
<p>The goals are to optimize digital to make the food bank’s operations more efficient and to create better experiences and support for its four key stakeholder groups. Chief among those are people without enough to eat, plus the approximately 600 food-distribution partners that GBFB works with to get food to them. GBFB hopes its digital-first approach will also improve interactions with donors and support its workforce.</p>
<p>“In the end, it’s all aligned with our strategic plan to close the meal gap and move people from being food insecure to food secure,” said Catherine D’Amato, CEO of GBFB.</p>
<h2>Challenges magnified by the crisis</h2>
<!-- -->
<p>Food banks had begun the journey to digital, but, like a lot of other organizations, they <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-covid-19-has-pushed-companies-over-the-technology-tipping-point-and-transformed-business-forever">accelerated their digital transformation efforts</a> during the pandemic out of necessity. Their main motivations were to deal with higher demand for food aid and to adhere to strict safety measures that limited in-person interactions.</p>
<p>Food banks employed more <a href="/featured-insights/food-security/making-a-difference-with-data">advanced data analytics</a> to match demand for food with changing sources of food supply, including government food-box programs. They brought on new tech­nologies to improve warehouse operations and to expand the network of community groups they partner with to provide services beyond food aid, such as help with healthcare and job hunting.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9c3e5c3b-38fd-44b8-b79c-b0fa5222a248"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9c3e5c3b-38fd-44b8-b79c-b0fa5222a248" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Eduardo Tobias Benoliel, Ana Calvo, Ignacio Felix, and Byron Ruby, “<a href="/featured-insights/food-security/transforming-food-banks-warehouse-operations-to-improve-critical-performance">Transforming food banks’ warehouse operations to improve critical performance</a>,” October 16, 2020; Kyle Hutzler, Pradeep Prabhala, Byron Ruby, and Galo Tocagni, “<a href="/featured-insights/food-security/turning-over-a-new-leaf-using-crisis-to-build-back-stronger">Turning over a new leaf: Using crisis to build back stronger</a>,” January 6, 2021.
    </span></span></span></a></span> Some embraced <a href="/featured-insights/food-security/food-banks-apply-2020-lessons-to-plan-for-their-future">more sophisticated forecasting models</a> to better predict the effect of changing economic conditions on the demand for food in their area.</p>
<p>When it comes to embracing digital, GBFB officials say they were early adopters. The organization had already replaced antiquated IT with newer systems. Four years ago, it implemented a NetSuite e-commerce platform so that it could take food orders from its food-distribution partners and order the food that the organization buys to supplement donated goods. GBFB also upgraded to a Salesforce customer-relationship-management system to manage interactions with donors and volunteers and to allow food pantries to schedule deliveries. In addition, most of its office staff, about 100 people, had been outfitted with laptops.</p>
<p>When the pandemic struck, GBFB helped its food-distribution partners convert to distributing food through curbside pickups, drive-through events, and other <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/beyond-contactless-operations-human-centered-customer-experience">forms of contactless delivery</a>. The laptops made it possible for office workers to immediately transition to working remotely.</p>
<p>But the crisis exposed deficiencies. GBFB had added applications for a single department or isolated process without considering how everything could or should work together. Other applications had been adopted because they were readily available, economical, or just because somebody wanted it. As a result, some departments “had all the bells and whistles,” but others still relied on manual processes, D’Amato said. “There wasn’t a cross-business knowledge base. Departments were very isolated,” she said.</p>
<p>The mishmash of systems and the lack of a unified data framework meant GBFB’s IT department did not have a method for prioritizing projects. Despite its previous efforts to upgrade, the food bank often fell short of serving its ultimate customer—people in need. Surveys of people with food insecurity and food-distribution customers showed that people sometimes missed getting food because they didn’t know the right location to visit or when it was open. They also couldn’t always get the type of food they wanted or speak English well enough to communicate with food-distributor personnel. Some were afraid to share the personal information that a distributor required.</p>
<p>Food-distribution partners had issues too, including the need to send data about food recipients to GBFB without knowing how that information would be used or what benefits to expect in return.</p>
<h2>Adopting digital to improve customer experience</h2>
<p>Once GBFB leaders felt they were adequately responding to the unprecedented increase in demand for food created by the pandemic, they began to think about the future. That meant figuring out how to move existing systems from good to great. In addition to becoming more efficient, the goal was to improve the experience that food-insecure individuals, food pantries
and community agencies, and donors have when they interact with the organization.</p>
<p>Improving the customer experience fits into GBFB’s strategic vision to ensure everyone in the 190 towns and cities it serves has reliable access to enough high-quality food for three healthy meals a day (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/food%20security/digital%20transformation%20comes%20to%20food%20banks/svgz-foodsecurity-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The Greater Boston Food Bank (GBFB) has begun its digital-transformation journey to make the community of eastern Massachusetts more food secure." src="/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/food%20security/digital%20transformation%20comes%20to%20food%20banks/svgz-foodsecurity-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>In taking such a step, GBFB is following the lead of other public and private entities that have been reworking their customer experiences to be more people-centric. <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-three-building-blocks-of-successful-customer-experience-transformations">Creating a customer experience</a> that meets new consumer needs and expectations has become important for any organization’s success, especially in the wake of the pandemic. Given the rapid rise in consumer expectation driven by companies such as Amazon, customer expe­rience and human-centered design have become significant differentiators. McKinsey <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-design/our-insights/the-business-value-of-design">research shows</a> that superior design is closely associated with superior performance, whether an organization provides physical goods—as is the case with food banks—or digital products and services, or a combination of these.</p>
<p>Working in a people-centric way is especially impor­tant for organizations that interact with marginalized groups, such as food-insecure individuals, who frequently face stigmas that affect whether and how they seek resources. For that reason, providing a positive, convenient customer experience makes it likelier that food-insecure individuals get the support they need.</p>
<p>GBFB partnered with McKinsey to review the organization’s existing technology setup and to create a digital strategic plan. Surveying food-distribution partners and people with food insecurities was part of that process. So was interviewing GBFB personnel in operations, IT, and other departments. Staff identified internal pain points that could be ameliorated through adoption of digital to create more efficient processes that ultimately could advance the Project Everest mission of delivering more food aid to people who need it.</p>
<p> The transformation team uncovered and sorted issues by which aspects of the organization they affected, such as service quality, cost, and risk. The team brainstormed options for making improve­ments, including where the food bank had existing capabilities that could be enhanced and where it may need to build solutions from scratch. From there, they identified short-term, midterm and long-term goals, and they did a cost-benefit analysis to determine which projects to work on first (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/food%20security/digital%20transformation%20comes%20to%20food%20banks/svgz-foodsecurity-ex2-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="GBFB has invested $5 million over three years to implement a digital-transformation journey that will increase its impact on the food-insecure community." src="/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/food%20security/digital%20transformation%20comes%20to%20food%20banks/svgz-foodsecurity-ex2-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>In addition to operating more efficiently, potential goals for the digital transformation included the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Make it easier for people to get food aid, and information about it, through innovations such as a statewide information hub and a shopping app. As part of this effort, the food bank hopes to incorporate more of food-aid recipients’ needs and perspectives into its customer journey (the different ways that people interact with the organization).</li>
    <li>Improve communications with food-distribution partners, including processes for placing orders that incorporate live, online help on demand and check-in tools for pantries to collect pertinent information from food recipients.</li>
    <li>Create a communications channel for distribution partners that shares resources customized to their needs and fosters
    better collaboration.</li>
    <li>Improve management of stakeholder relation­ships and donation processes.</li>
    <li>Use predictive analytics to improve the food bank’s product mix.</li>
    <li>Use digital check-ins, scheduling, and sequencing to make pickups at GBFB’s warehouse faster and simpler.</li>
    <li>Create an end-to-end digital experience for donations.</li>
    <li>Reduce repetitive work and daily tasks for GBFB employees.</li>
    <li>Create an “innovation lab” to vet ideas and identify how technology could help the food bank achieve its mission more efficiently.</li>
</ul>
<p>GBFB created a position for a vice president of digital strategy to oversee the organization’s digital-transformation effort. The organization hired Unmesh Gandhi, a software architect turned management adviser with experience in corporate strategy and digital transformation. “The ultimate goal is to make quick decisions and lower costs and risks,” Gandhi said. “Another goal is to deliver continuous improvement,” so systems can evolve as needs change, he said.</p>
<p>The price tag of the food bank’s digital transfor­mation might sound daunting—$5 million represents a two- to threefold increase over what the food bank would normally spend on resources, technology, and engineering in a three-year period. But, despite the price tag, many of the changes aren’t necessarily difficult; they are simply steps that the food bank hasn’t taken before and that require working in new ways, D’Amato said. For that reason, a major portion of the transformation will be helping the GBFB staff assimilate the changes. “Our biggest issue will be the cultural shift and the impact on the team to do things differently,” she said.</p>
<h2>Other innovations</h2>
<p>GBFB plans to increase access by shortening the figurative distance between the food bank and its partners, and ultimately people in need. Its willingness to innovate extends even further, including working with an array of outside partners to test new ideas and stretch what it can provide.</p>
<p>In early June, GBFB announced a deal with Amazon, which is donating the services of a full-size tractor-trailer and driver once a week to deliver food from the food bank’s 117,000-square-foot distribution warehouse in Boston to a satellite dock in New Bedford that serves about 45 food-distribution partners in the area.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d778bd6a-eb38-4577-b404-48076ab06d94"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d778bd6a-eb38-4577-b404-48076ab06d94" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“The Greater Boston Food Bank partners with Amazon on food distribution to New Bedford area,” The Greater Boston Food Bank, June 9, 2021, gbfb.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Amazon has committed to moving 1 million pounds of food in an as-yet-unspecified time period, according to a GBFB spokesperson.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="364a0918-72f5-493c-92f6-93261e64ab74"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="364a0918-72f5-493c-92f6-93261e64ab74" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Audrey Cooney, “Amazon to help food bank ship 1 million pounds of food to New Bedford,” <em>Herald News</em>, June 10, 2021, heraldnews.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>This past summer, GBFB teamed up with Massachusetts Institute of Technology to test a prototype of a warehouse-disinfectant robot in the food bank’s distribution warehouse.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d93b4211-6594-4eb5-b57b-819fe468212b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d93b4211-6594-4eb5-b57b-819fe468212b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Darrell Etherington, “In effort to fight COVID-19, MIT robot gets to work disinfecting The Greater Boston Food Bank,” <em>TechCrunch</em>, June 29, 2020, techcrunch.com.</span></span></span></a></span> The robotic system, created by MIT’s Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory and Ava Robotics, disinfects surfaces that might have come in contact with the coronavirus and eliminates airborne virus particles, according to the lab.</p>
<p>In February 2020, GBFB partnered with the Mystic Valley YMCA in Medford to open the Mystic Community Market food pantry to serve the com­munity there and to test food-distribution models.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b19d69db-3695-404e-9582-ef14af8d20b8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b19d69db-3695-404e-9582-ef14af8d20b8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“A collaborative approach: Alleviating hunger in Mystic Valley,” The Greater Boston Food Bank, June 4, 2020, gbfb.org.</span></span></span></a></span> In one example, when the pandemic hit, Mystic Community Market introduced a mobile app for people in need to order fresh produce, protein, dairy, and other foods and pick them up curbside. Separately, GBFB partnered with YMCA Southcoast to create and fund the Full Plate Project, a food hub serving five affiliated YMCA branches that aims to distribute one million pounds of food in 2021.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="33559c1f-13df-47bb-91b8-50f83708decd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="33559c1f-13df-47bb-91b8-50f83708decd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Full plate project,” YMCA Southcoast, ymcasouthcoast.org.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>GBFB is using the digital-transformation project to reduce its carbon footprint through improved energy use and digital monitoring and automation, among other things. Toward that end, GBFB has optimized truck routes to conserve fuel and maintains Silver LEED certification for its warehouse.</p>
<h2>Next steps</h2>
<p>GBFB is still in an early phase of implementing the plan. So far, the organization is weighing McKinsey’s recommendations along with findings from the transformation project’s initial discovery and assessment phase. As they launch initiatives, food bank leaders say they will depend on data to track measurable effects of the changes while staying open to innovation and experimentation.</p>
<p>“We have a high affinity for creativity,” D’Amato said. “We’re willing to try new things.”</p>

banks","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"73243f5b-0315-4384-9811-c690a1669898","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Digital transformation comes to food banks"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The Greater Boston Food Bank\u0026rsquo;s $5 million reinvention as a digital-first enterprise has one overriding goal\u0026mdash;to put more of its resources toward ending hunger."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-10-26T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCompanies aren\u0026rsquo;t \u003c/strong\u003ethe only organizations remaking themselves into digital enterprises to meet customers\u0026rsquo; needs. When the COVID-19 pandemic hit, food banks\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/digital-transformation-improving-the-odds-of-success\"\u003e accelerated their digital trans­formations\u003c/a\u003e to get more food more quickly to more people in need.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Pullquote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eOne of them is The Greater Boston Food Bank (GBFB), which estimates it distributed 56 percent more food in 2020 than the previous year because of the pandemic.[[Footnote 1]] Although crisis-related hardships have begun to recede, demand for charitable food aid in GBFB\u0026rsquo;s eastern Massachusetts service area remains significant. It prompted the food bank\u0026rsquo;s leaders to rethink their practice of adopting technology in a piecemeal fashion. Instead, they\u0026rsquo;re in the initial phase of implementing an approximately three-year, $5 million plan\u0026mdash;dubbed \u0026ldquo;Project Everest\u0026rdquo;\u0026mdash;to operate as a unified, digital-first organization.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe goals are to optimize digital to make the food bank\u0026rsquo;s operations more efficient and to create better experiences and support for its four key stakeholder groups. Chief among those are people without enough to eat, plus the approximately 600 food-distribution partners that GBFB works with to get food to them. GBFB hopes its digital-first approach will also improve interactions with donors and support its workforce.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;In the end, it\u0026rsquo;s all aligned with our strategic plan to close the meal gap and move people from being food insecure to food secure,\u0026rdquo; said Catherine D\u0026rsquo;Amato, CEO of GBFB.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eChallenges magnified by the crisis\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eFood banks had begun the journey to digital, but, like a lot of other organizations, they \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-covid-19-has-pushed-companies-over-the-technology-tipping-point-and-transformed-business-forever\"\u003eaccelerated their digital transformation efforts\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;during the pandemic out of necessity. Their main motivations were to deal with higher demand for food aid and to adhere to strict safety measures that limited in-person interactions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFood banks employed more \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/food-security/making-a-difference-with-data\"\u003eadvanced data analytics\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to match demand for food with changing sources of food supply, including government food-box programs. They brought on new tech­nologies to improve warehouse operations\u0026nbsp;and to expand the network of community groups they partner with to provide services beyond food aid, such as help with healthcare and job hunting.[[Footnote 2]] Some embraced \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/food-security/food-banks-apply-2020-lessons-to-plan-for-their-future\"\u003emore sophisticated forecasting models\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to better predict the effect of changing economic conditions on the demand for food in their area.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen it comes to embracing digital, GBFB officials say they were early adopters. The organization had already replaced antiquated IT with newer systems. Four years ago, it implemented a NetSuite e-commerce platform so that it could take food orders from its food-distribution partners and order the food that the organization buys to supplement donated goods. GBFB also upgraded to a Salesforce customer-relationship-management system to manage interactions with donors and volunteers and to allow food pantries to schedule deliveries. In addition, most of its office staff, about 100 people, had been outfitted with laptops.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen the pandemic struck, GBFB helped its food-distribution partners convert to distributing food through curbside pickups, drive-through events, and other \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/beyond-contactless-operations-human-centered-customer-experience\"\u003eforms of contactless delivery\u003c/a\u003e. The laptops made it possible for office workers to immediately transition to working remotely.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut the crisis exposed deficiencies. GBFB had added applications for a single department or isolated process without considering how everything could or should work together. Other applications had been adopted because they were readily available, economical, or just because somebody wanted it. As a result, some departments \u0026ldquo;had all the bells and whistles,\u0026rdquo; but others still relied on manual processes, D\u0026rsquo;Amato said. \u0026ldquo;There wasn\u0026rsquo;t a cross-business knowledge base. Departments were very isolated,\u0026rdquo; she said.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe mishmash of systems and the lack of a unified data framework meant GBFB\u0026rsquo;s IT department did not have a method for prioritizing projects. Despite its previous efforts to upgrade, the food bank often fell short of serving its ultimate customer\u0026mdash;people in need. Surveys of people with food insecurity and food-distribution customers showed that people sometimes missed getting food because they didn\u0026rsquo;t know the right location to visit or when it was open. They also couldn\u0026rsquo;t always get the type of food they wanted or speak English well enough to communicate with food-distributor personnel. Some were afraid to share the personal information that a distributor required.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFood-distribution partners had issues too, including the need to send data about food recipients to GBFB without knowing how that information would be used or what benefits to expect in return.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eAdopting digital to improve customer experience\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce GBFB leaders felt they were adequately responding to the unprecedented increase in demand for food created by the pandemic, they began to think about the future. That meant figuring out how to move existing systems from good to great. In addition to becoming more efficient, the goal was to improve the experience that food-insecure individuals, food pantries\nand community agencies, and donors have when they interact with the organization.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eImproving the customer experience fits into GBFB\u0026rsquo;s strategic vision to ensure everyone in the 190 towns and cities it serves has reliable access to enough high-quality food for three healthy meals a day (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn taking such a step, GBFB is following the lead of other public and private entities that have been reworking their customer experiences to be more people-centric. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-three-building-blocks-of-successful-customer-experience-transformations\"\u003eCreating a customer experience\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that meets new consumer needs and expectations has become important for any organization\u0026rsquo;s success, especially in the wake of the pandemic. Given the rapid rise in consumer expectation driven by companies such as Amazon, customer expe­rience and human-centered design have become significant differentiators. McKinsey \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-design/our-insights/the-business-value-of-design\"\u003eresearch shows\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that superior design is closely associated with superior performance, whether an organization provides physical goods\u0026mdash;as is the case with food banks\u0026mdash;or digital products and services, or a combination of these.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWorking in a people-centric way is especially impor­tant for organizations that interact with marginalized groups, such as food-insecure individuals, who frequently face stigmas that affect whether and how they seek resources. For that reason, providing a positive, convenient customer experience makes it likelier that food-insecure individuals get the support they need.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGBFB partnered with McKinsey to review the organization\u0026rsquo;s existing technology setup and to create a digital strategic plan. Surveying food-distribution partners and people with food insecurities was part of that process. So was interviewing GBFB personnel in operations, IT, and other departments. Staff identified internal pain points that could be ameliorated through adoption of digital to create more efficient processes that ultimately could advance the Project Everest mission of delivering more food aid to people who need it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e The transformation team uncovered and sorted issues by which aspects of the organization they affected, such as service quality, cost, and risk. The team brainstormed options for making improve­ments, including where the food bank had existing capabilities that could be enhanced and where it may need to build solutions from scratch. From there, they identified short-term, midterm and long-term goals, and they did a cost-benefit analysis to determine which projects to work on first (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to operating more efficiently, potential goals for the digital transformation included the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMake it easier for people to get food aid, and information about it, through innovations such as a statewide information hub and a shopping app. As part of this effort, the food bank hopes to incorporate more of food-aid recipients\u0026rsquo; needs and perspectives into its customer journey (the different ways that people interact with the organization).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eImprove communications with food-distribution partners, including processes for placing orders that incorporate live, online help on demand and check-in tools for pantries to collect pertinent information from food recipients.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCreate a communications channel for distribution partners that shares resources customized to their needs and fosters\n    better collaboration.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eImprove management of stakeholder relation­ships and donation processes.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eUse predictive analytics to improve the food bank\u0026rsquo;s product mix.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eUse digital check-ins, scheduling, and sequencing to make pickups at GBFB\u0026rsquo;s warehouse faster and simpler.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCreate an end-to-end digital experience for donations.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eReduce repetitive work and daily tasks for GBFB employees.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCreate an \u0026ldquo;innovation lab\u0026rdquo; to vet ideas and identify how technology could help the food bank achieve its mission more efficiently.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGBFB created a position for a vice president of digital strategy to oversee the organization\u0026rsquo;s digital-transformation effort. The organization hired Unmesh Gandhi, a software architect turned management adviser with experience in corporate strategy and digital transformation. \u0026ldquo;The ultimate goal is to make quick decisions and lower costs and risks,\u0026rdquo; Gandhi said. \u0026ldquo;Another goal is to deliver continuous improvement,\u0026rdquo; so systems can evolve as needs change, he said.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe price tag of the food bank\u0026rsquo;s digital transfor­mation might sound daunting\u0026mdash;$5 million represents a two- to threefold increase over what the food bank would normally spend on resources, technology, and engineering in a three-year period. But, despite the price tag, many of the changes aren\u0026rsquo;t necessarily difficult; they are simply steps that the food bank hasn\u0026rsquo;t taken before and that require working in new ways, D\u0026rsquo;Amato said. For that reason, a major portion of the transformation will be helping the GBFB staff assimilate the changes. \u0026ldquo;Our biggest issue will be the cultural shift and the impact on the team to do things differently,\u0026rdquo; she said.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eOther innovations\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGBFB plans to increase access by shortening the figurative distance between the food bank and its partners, and ultimately people in need. Its willingness to innovate extends even further, including working with an array of outside partners to test new ideas and stretch what it can provide.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn early June, GBFB announced a deal with Amazon, which is donating the services of a full-size tractor-trailer and driver once a week to deliver food from the food bank\u0026rsquo;s 117,000-square-foot distribution warehouse in Boston to a satellite dock in New Bedford that serves about 45 food-distribution partners in the area.[[Footnote 3]] Amazon has committed to moving 1 million pounds of food in an as-yet-unspecified time period, according to a GBFB spokesperson.[[Footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis past summer, GBFB teamed up with Massachusetts Institute of Technology to test a prototype of a warehouse-disinfectant robot in the food bank\u0026rsquo;s distribution warehouse.[[Footnote 5]] The robotic system, created by MIT\u0026rsquo;s Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory and Ava Robotics, disinfects surfaces that might have come in contact with the coronavirus and eliminates airborne virus particles, according to the lab.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn February 2020, GBFB partnered with the Mystic Valley YMCA in Medford to open the Mystic Community Market food pantry to serve the com­munity there and to test food-distribution models.[[Footnote 6]] In one example, when the pandemic hit, Mystic Community Market introduced a mobile app for people in need to order fresh produce, protein, dairy, and other foods and pick them up curbside. Separately, GBFB partnered with YMCA Southcoast to create and fund the Full Plate Project, a food hub serving five affiliated YMCA branches that aims to distribute one million pounds of food in 2021.[[Footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGBFB is using the digital-transformation project to reduce its carbon footprint through improved energy use and digital monitoring and automation, among other things. Toward that end, GBFB has optimized truck routes to conserve fuel and maintains Silver LEED certification for its warehouse.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eNext steps\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGBFB is still in an early phase of implementing the plan. So far, the organization is weighing McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s recommendations along with findings from the transformation project\u0026rsquo;s initial discovery and assessment phase. As they launch initiatives, food bank leaders say they will depend on data to track measurable effects of the changes while staying open to innovation and experimentation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;We have a high affinity for creativity,\u0026rdquo; D\u0026rsquo;Amato said. \u0026ldquo;We\u0026rsquo;re willing to try new things.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE
